noun.description: A continuous area or expanse which is free, available, or unoccupied.
examples: a table took up much of the space
we shall all be living together in a small space
he backed out of the parking space
the space between a wall and a utility pipe

noun.description: The dimensions of height, depth, and width within which all things exist and move.
examples: the work gives the sense of a journey in space and time

noun.description: An interval of time (often used to suggest that the time is short considering what has happened or been achieved in it)
examples: both their cars were stolen in the space of three days

noun.description: The portion of a text or document available or needed to write about a subject.
examples: there is no space to give further details

noun.description: The freedom and scope to live, think, and develop in a way that suits one.
examples: a teenager needing her own space

noun.description: One of two possible states of a signal in certain systems.

verb.description: Position (two or more items) at a distance from one another.
Be or become distracted, euphoric, or disoriented, especially from taking drugs; cease to be aware of one's surroundings.
examples: I was so tired that I began to feel totally spaced out
I kind of space out for a few minutes

phrases: A special gig to launch this anti-war movement will take place shortly; watch this space for further developments.
More details should follow soon, so watch this space!
For further information on the band's progress, including gigs, watch this space.
A lot more information will be provided in the coming weeks, so watch this space.
Many more interests will be catered for, so watch this space for more information.
origin: Middle English: shortening of Old French espace, from Latin spatium. Current verb senses date from the late 17th century.
